==Chinese==
{{zh-forms}}

===Etymology===
This is a late character, and the divergent readings in various topolects may or may not be cognate.

The Mandarin reading came from {{zh-l|摔|to fling, to throw, to fall down}}, which can be traced to *''srut'' in Old Chinese. It can be compared with {{cog|bo|རུད||slip, that which has slipped down, falling mass, landslides}}, {{m|bo|རུད་རུད་པོ||loosened, disintegrated, rough}}.

The Cantonese reading is probably unrelated, though it may reflect a descendant of the archaic pronunciation *''rut'' and hence be cognate with Mandarin. Either way, it is evidently from the same source as Min Nan {{zh-l|甪|tr=lut|to come off, to slip loose}}, Zhuang {{m|za|lot||to come loose and drop off (due to loose tying)}}, and Vietnamese {{m|vi|lột||to peel, to strip off}}. May be compared with Tibetan {{m|bo|ལོད་པོ||relaxed, careless}}, {{m|bo|ལྷོད་པོ||relaxed, loose, lax}}, and the Chinese word family of {{zh-l|*兌}} (*''lot'', > {{zh-l|*脫|to come off}}, {{zh-l|*蛻|exuviae}}). Unlikely to be related to {{zh-l|落|to fall, to drop off}}.
